results.title: Elements, compounds and mixtures
results.creator_credit: Tarquin Cardona, Bob Starner, Olga Palacio, First Light Pictures and Schlessinger Media
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Physical science in action”.
Every element in the periodic table is made up of atoms, and every atom in an element contains the same number of protons. This program examines how elements combine in mixtures, compounds and solutions to make up the world in which we live. Students are taken on a fun journey, using real-life examples to explain the properties of elements, as well as concepts such as chemical bonding and heterogenous/homogenous mixtures. Suitable for Upper primary/lower secondary students. Teachers notes included.

results.title: Elements organised: the periodic table
results.creator_credit: Open University, BBC, Tony Jolly and David Jackson
results.brief_description: A series of excellent demonstrations, with graphics, showing how the great variety in the behaviour of the elements can be organised into a systematic structure, the Periodic Table. Please note that there is some background noise on the tape. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Elements of tempering, normalizing and annealing
results.creator_credit: F.E. Brooker, United States. Office of Education and Audio Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Engineering heat treatment of steel”.
Shows how steel is tempered; how the structure, toughness and hardness of a plain carbon steel change at progressive tempering stages; how steel is normalised, by furnace heating and subsequent cooling in still air; how steel is annealed and how such an annealing process relieves stresses in steel castings and softens the metal.
results.creator_credit_for_label: F.E. Brooker, United States. Office of Education and Audio Productions

results.title: Elements of survival. Part 2. Food
results.creator_credit: Canadian Broadcasting Corporation and Doug Lower
results.brief_description: This program explores the myth that there are vast tracts of arable land, capable of supporting human populations, no matter what their numbers. Looking at world politics and economics, as well as the availability of land, water and energy resources, it explores the ever-present wall of hunger that separates the “haves” from the “have nots” and studies possibilities for a more equitable distribution of present food resources.

results.title: Elements of survival. Part 1. Populations
results.creator_credit: Canadian Broadcasting Corporation and Doug Lower
results.brief_description: First of a two-part series this episode focuses on the population spiral and looks at mankind from pre-history to the present explosion with its doubling of world population about every 35 years. The film looks at the possible consequences of unchecked growth, and the wide gulf between the haves and the have-nots.

results.title: Elements of surface hardening
results.creator_credit: F.E. Brooker, United States. Office of Education and Audio Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Engineering heat treatment of steel”.
Shows how steel is pack and gas carburised; how a thin, hard case is obtained by cyaniding; how nitriding is used to obtain a very hard case; and how steel is flame and induction hardened.

results.title: Elements of hardening
results.creator_credit: F.E. Brooker, United States. Federal Security Agency, United States. Office of Education and Audio Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Engineering heat treatment of steel”.
Shows how steel is quench-hardened; how the structures and hardness of steels with different carbon content change at progressive quench-hardening stages; how an iron-carbon diagram is constructed and what information may be derived from an analysis of such a diagram.

results.title: Elements
results.brief_description: This program tracks the journey of Western Australia’s natural gas from the North Rankin “A” Gas and Condensate production platform, through its 134 km journey to the Burrup Peninsula and through the liquefication process, concluding with delivery to Japan. The video explains various elements of the LNG plant including the sulfinol column, dehydration unit, scrub column, heat exchanger, storage tanks and control room. The program concludes with details of the LNG ships and their delivery of LNG to Japanese power utilities.
